message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has stage II adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe without evidence of distant metastases. Surgery, such as lobectomy, is the preferred treatment for early-stage lung cancer. Radiation therapy and chemotherapy may also be options but are typically used in later stages or when surgery is not an option. A wedge resection may not be sufficient for this stage of cancer. Therefore, scheduling a lobectomy is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been diagnosed with stage II lung adenocarcinoma, and a lobectomy is the preferred treatment option for this stage. Radiation therapy and wedge resection are options for earlier stages, and chemotherapy is usually reserved for later stages or as an adjuvant therapy. The patient's spirometry and DLCO results will need to be taken into consideration during the surgical procedure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has stage II adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe without evidence of distant metastases. Lobectomy is the recommended treatment for early-stage non-small cell lung cancer. The patient’s spirometry and DLCO results support the ability to tolerate surgery. Radiation therapy alone is not the first-line treatment for early-stage non-small cell lung cancer. Wedge resection is an option but not the first-line treatment. Chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide is used for more advanced stages of non-small cell lung cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has stage II adenocarcinoma of the lung without distant metastases. Lobectomy is the most effective treatment for stage I and II non-small cell lung cancer, which is resectable. Radiation therapy and wedge resection are usually reserved for patients who are unable to undergo lobectomy due to various reasons. Administering chemotherapy is not mentioned as a treatment option in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has stage II adenocarcinoma of the lung, and the presence of wheezing and reduced FEV1 and DLCO suggests an obstructive component. Lobectomy is the standard of care for stage II non-small cell lung cancer. Radiation therapy or wedge resection may not be as effective. Cisplatin and etoposide may be used in conjunction with surgery for some patients, but surgery is the primary treatment modality.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has stage II adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe but without distant metastases. The inspiratory wheezing at the left lung base suggests that the tumor might be obstructing some air passages. Since the patient is otherwise healthy except for his hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, the most appropriate next step is to schedule lobectomy, which involves removing the entire lobe of the lung containing the tumor. Radiation therapy and wedge resection are considered for patients with early stage lung cancer, but lobectomy is the preferred treatment for stage II non-small cell lung cancer. Administering cisplatin and etoposide is not considered until further staging workup is completed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has stage II lung cancer without evidence of distant metastases, which means surgery is a viable option. The inspiratory wheezing at the left lung base likely indicates obstruction due to the tumor, but radiation therapy or wedge resection may not completely remove the tumor. Administering cisplatin and etoposide is an option for chemotherapy, but surgery is still the preferred initial treatment for stage II lung cancer. Therefore, scheduling a lobectomy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been diagnosed with stage II adenocarcinoma and surgery is typically the preferred treatment for localized lung cancer. In this case, a lobectomy is the most appropriate next step. Radiation therapy and chemotherapy may also be considered, but surgery is typically the first-line treatment option for stage II lung cancer. A wedge resection may not be sufficient for the size and location of the tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has stage II adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe and wheezing at the left lung base. Lobectomy is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient. Radiation therapy and wedge resection are options for early-stage non-small cell lung cancer, but the patient has stage II disease. Administration of cisplatin and etoposide is a treatment option for extensive stage small cell lung cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been diagnosed with stage II adenocarcinoma of the left lower lung lobe, and surgery is the most appropriate next step. Radiation therapy and chemotherapy may be added after surgery. The wheezing at the left lung base suggests that the tumor is obstructing airflow in that area. A wedge resection may not be sufficient to remove the entire tumor.
